pli-tv-kd5:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying on the Vulture Peak at Rājagaha.

pli-tv-kd5:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro asītiyā gāmasahassesu issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.2.eng: At that time King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha ruled over eighty thousand villages,

pli-tv-kd5:1.1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena campāyaṃ soṇo nāma koḷiviso seṭṭhiputto sukhumālo hoti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.3.eng: and at Campā there was a wealthy merchant who had a son called Soṇa Koḷivisa. He had been raised in great comfort,

pli-tv-kd5:1.1.4.eng: so much so that he had hairs growing on the soles of his feet.

pli-tv-kd5:1.1.5.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro tāni asīti gāmikasahassāni sannipātāpetvā kenacideva karaṇīyena soṇassa koḷivisassa santike dūtaṃ pāhesi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.5.eng: On one occasion, King Bimbisāra had the chiefs of those eighty thousand villages gathered because of some business. He then sent a message to Soṇa,

pli-tv-kd5:1.2.1.pli: Atha kho soṇassa koḷivisassa mātāpitaro soṇaṃ koḷivisaṃ etadavocuṃ—

pli-tv-kd5:1.2.2.eng: “Soṇa, the king wishes to see your feet,

pli-tv-kd5:1.2.3.pli: Mā kho tvaṃ, tāta soṇa, yena rājā tena pāde abhippasāreyyāsi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.3.eng: but don’t point them at him.

pli-tv-kd5:1.2.4.eng: If you just sit down cross-legged in front him,

pli-tv-kd5:1.2.5.eng: he’ll be able to see them.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.2.6.pli: Atha kho soṇaṃ koḷivisaṃ sivikāya ānesuṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.6.eng: They then sent him away on a palanquin,

pli-tv-kd5:1.2.7.pli: Atha kho soṇo koḷiviso yena rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ seniyaṃ bimbisāraṃ abhivādetvā rañño purato pallaṅkena nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.7.eng: and Soṇa went to King Bimbisāra. Upon arrival, he bowed to the king and sat down cross-legged in front of him.

pli-tv-kd5:1.2.8.pli: Addasā kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro soṇassa koḷivisassa pādatalesu lomāni jātāni.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.8.eng: The king saw the hairs growing on the soles of his feet.

pli-tv-kd5:1.3.1.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro tāni asīti gāmikasahassāni diṭṭhadhammike atthe anusāsitvā uyyojesi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.1.eng: Then, after instructing those eighty thousand chiefs in worldly matters, the king dismissed them, saying,

pli-tv-kd5:1.3.2.pli: “tumhe khvattha, bhaṇe, mayā diṭṭhadhammike atthe anusāsitā;

pli-tv-kd5:1.3.3.eng: Now go and visit the Buddha.

pli-tv-kd5:1.3.4.pli: so no bhagavā samparāyike atthe anusāsissatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.4.eng: He will instruct us about the afterlife.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.3.5.pli: Atha kho tāni asīti gāmikasahassāni yena gijjhakūṭo pabbato tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.5.eng: Those village chiefs then went to the Vulture Peak.

pli-tv-kd5:1.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāgato bhagavato upaṭṭhāko hoti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.4.1.eng: There they approached Venerable Sāgata, who at that time was the Buddha’s attendant.

pli-tv-kd5:1.4.2.pli: Atha kho tāni asīti gāmikasahassāni yenāyasmā sāgato tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāgataṃ etadavocuṃ—

pli-tv-kd5:1.4.3.pli: “imāni, bhante, asīti gāmikasahassāni idhūpasaṅkantāni bhagavantaṃ dassanāya;
pli-tv-kd5:1.4.3.eng: “Venerable, these eighty thousand chiefs have come to visit the Buddha.

pli-tv-kd5:1.4.4.pli: sādhu mayaṃ, bhante, labheyyāma bhagavantaṃ dassanāyā”ti.

pli-tv-kd5:1.4.5.pli: “Tena hi tumhe āyasmanto muhuttaṃ idheva tāva hotha, yāvāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ paṭivedemī”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.4.5.eng: “Well then, please wait here for a moment, while I announce you to the Buddha.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāgato tesaṃ asītiyā gāmikasahassānaṃ purato pekkhamānānaṃ pāṭikāya nimujjitvā bhagavato purato ummujjitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd5:1.5.1.eng: Then, while those village chiefs were watching, he sunk into the stone slab he was standing on and emerged in front of the Buddha. He said to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd5:1.5.2.pli: “imāni, bhante, asīti gāmikasahassāni idhūpasaṅkantāni bhagavantaṃ dassanāya;
pli-tv-kd5:1.5.2.eng: “Sir, eighty thousand village chiefs have come to visit you.

pli-tv-kd5:1.5.3.eng: What would you like to do?”

pli-tv-kd5:1.5.4.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, sāgata, vihārapacchāyāyaṃ āsanaṃ paññapehī”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.5.4.eng: “Well then, Sāgata, prepare a seat in the shade of the dwelling.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.6.2.pli: kho āyasmā sāgato bhagavato paṭissuṇitvā pīṭhaṃ gahetvā bhagavato purato nimujjitvā tesaṃ asītiyā gāmikasahassānaṃ purato pekkhamānānaṃ pāṭikāya ummujjitvā vihārapacchāyāyaṃ āsanaṃ paññapeti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.6.2.eng: He took a bench, sunk down in front of the Buddha, and as those village chiefs were watching, he once more emerged from that stone slab. He then prepared a seat in the shade of the dwelling,

pli-tv-kd5:1.6.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā vihārā nikkhamitvā vihārapacchāyāyaṃ paññatte āsane nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.6.3.eng: after which the Buddha came out and sat down.

pli-tv-kd5:1.7.1.pli: Atha kho tāni asīti gāmikasahassāni yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.1.eng: Those eighty thousand chiefs approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.

pli-tv-kd5:1.7.2.pli: Atha kho tāni asīti gāmikasahassāni āyasmantaṃyeva sāgataṃ samannāharanti, no tathā bhagavantaṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.2.eng: But they were preoccupied with Sāgata, not with the Buddha.

pli-tv-kd5:1.7.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tesaṃ asītiyā gāmikasahassānaṃ cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya āyasmantaṃ sāgataṃ āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.3.eng: After reading their minds, the Buddha said to Sāgata,

pli-tv-kd5:1.7.4.pli: “tena hi tvaṃ, sāgata, bhiyyoso mattāya uttari manussadhammaṃ iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassehī”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.4.eng: “Well then, Sāgata, show us more superhuman abilities, more wonders of supernormal power.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.7.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā sāgato bhagavato paṭissuṇitvā vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe caṅkamatipi, tiṭṭhatipi, nisīdatipi, seyyampi kappeti, dhūmāyatipi pajjalatipi, antaradhāyatipi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.5.eng: Saying, “Yes, sir,” he rose up in the air, walked back and forth in space, and he stood, sat down, and lay down there. He emitted smoke and fire, and then disappeared.

pli-tv-kd5:1.8.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāgato ākāse antalikkhe anekavihitaṃ uttari manussadhammaṃ iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassetvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.1.eng: After this display of supernormal powers, he bowed down at the feet of the Buddha, and said,

pli-tv-kd5:1.8.6.pli: Atha kho tāni asīti gāmikasahassāni “acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho.
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.6.eng: Those eighty thousand chiefs thought, “It’s astonishing and amazing

pli-tv-kd5:1.8.7.pli: Sāvakopi nāma evaṃ mahiddhiko bhavissati, evaṃ mahānubhāvo, aho nūna satthā”ti bhagavantaṃyeva samannāharanti, no tathā āyasmantaṃ sāgataṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.7.eng: that even a disciple should be so powerful and mighty. Imagine what the teacher must be like!” Now they paid attention to the Buddha, not to Sāgata.

pli-tv-kd5:1.9.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tesaṃ asītiyā gāmikasahassānaṃ cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ—
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.1.eng: Having read their minds, the Buddha gave those eighty thousand chiefs a progressive talk—

pli-tv-kd5:1.9.2.pli: dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ, kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.2.eng: on generosity, morality, and heaven; on the downside, degradation, and defilement of worldly pleasures; and he revealed the benefits of renunciation.

pli-tv-kd5:1.9.3.pli: Yadā te bhagavā aññāsi kallacitte, muducitte, vinīvaraṇacitte, udaggacitte, pasannacitte, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā, taṃ pakāsesi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.3.eng: When the Buddha knew that their minds were ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:

pli-tv-kd5:1.9.4.eng: suffering, its origin, its end, and the path.

pli-tv-kd5:1.9.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.5.eng: Just as a clean and stainless cloth absorbs dye properly,

pli-tv-kd5:1.9.6.pli: evamevaṃ tesaṃ asītiyā gāmikasahassānaṃ tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.6.eng: so too, while they were sitting right there, those eighty thousand village chiefs experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:

pli-tv-kd5:1.9.7.eng: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.10.1.pli: Te diṭṭhadhammā pattadhammā viditadhammā pariyogāḷhadhammā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.1.eng: They had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it. They had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. They then said to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd5:1.10.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya—
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.3.eng: Just as one might set upright what’s overturned, or reveal what’s hidden, or show the way to one who’s lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that

pli-tv-kd5:1.10.4.eng: those with eyes might see what’s there—

pli-tv-kd5:1.10.5.eng: just so has the Buddha made the Teaching clear in many ways.

pli-tv-kd5:1.10.6.pli: Ete mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma.
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.6.eng: We go for refuge to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd5:1.10.7.eng: the Teaching, and the Sangha of monks.

pli-tv-kd5:1.10.8.pli: Upāsake no bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṃ gate”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.8.eng: Please accept us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.11.0.eng: The going forth of Soṇa Koḷivisa

pli-tv-kd5:1.11.2.pli: “yathā yathā kho ahaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ;
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.2.eng: “The way I understand the Buddha’s Teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.

pli-tv-kd5:1.11.3.pli: yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.3.eng: Why don’t I cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth into homelessness?”

pli-tv-kd5:1.11.4.pli: Atha kho tāni asīti gāmikasahassāni bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkamiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.4.eng: When those eighty-four thousand chiefs had rejoiced and expressed their appreciation for the Buddha’s teaching, they got up from their seats, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with their right sides toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd5:1.12.1.pli: Atha kho soṇo koḷiviso acirapakkantesu tesu asītiyā gāmikasahassesu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.1.eng: Soon after they had left, Soṇa approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd5:1.12.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho soṇo koḷiviso bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd5:1.12.3.pli: “yathā yathāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.3.eng: “Sir, the way I understand the Buddha’s Teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.

pli-tv-kd5:1.12.4.pli: Icchāmahaṃ, bhante, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajituṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.4.eng: I want to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth into homelessness.

pli-tv-kd5:1.12.5.eng: Please give me the going forth.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.12.6.pli: Alattha kho soṇo koḷiviso bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.6.eng: Soṇa received the going forth and the full ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

pli-tv-kd5:1.12.7.pli: Acirupasampanno ca panāyasmā soṇo sītavane viharati.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.7.eng: Soon after his ordination, while staying in Cool Grove,

pli-tv-kd5:1.13.1.eng: Venerable Soṇa practiced walking meditation with so much energy that his feet cracked.

pli-tv-kd5:1.13.2.pli: Caṅkamo lohitena phuṭo hoti, seyyathāpi gavāghātanaṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.2.eng: His walking path became covered in blood, like a slaughterhouse.

pli-tv-kd5:1.13.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmato soṇassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.3.eng: Then, while reflecting in private, he thought,

pli-tv-kd5:1.13.4.pli: “ye kho keci bhagavato sāvakā āraddhavīriyā viharanti, ahaṃ tesaṃ aññataro.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.4.eng: “I’m one of the Buddha’s energetic disciples,

pli-tv-kd5:1.13.5.pli: Atha ca pana me nānupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccati.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.5.eng: yet my mind isn’t freed from the corruptions through letting go.

pli-tv-kd5:1.13.6.pli: Saṃvijjanti kho pana me kule bhogā;

pli-tv-kd5:1.13.7.pli: sakkā bhoge ca bhuñjituṃ, puññāni ca kātuṃ.

pli-tv-kd5:1.13.8.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjeyyaṃ, puññāni ca kareyyan”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.8.eng: Why don’t I return to the lower life, enjoy wealth, and make merit?”

pli-tv-kd5:1.14.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmato soṇassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.1.eng: Just then the Buddha read Soṇa’s mind.

pli-tv-kd5:1.14.2.pli: seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—gijjhakūṭe pabbate antarahito sītavane pāturahosi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.2.eng: And, as a strong man might bend or stretch his arm, the Buddha disappeared from the Vulture Peak and appeared in Cool Grove.

pli-tv-kd5:1.14.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ senāsanacārikaṃ āhiṇḍanto yenāyasmato soṇassa caṅkamo tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.3.eng: Soon afterwards as the Buddha and a number of monks were walking about the dwellings, they came to Soṇa’s walking path.

pli-tv-kd5:1.14.4.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmato soṇassa caṅkamaṃ lohitena phuṭaṃ, disvāna bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.4.eng: The Buddha looked at it and asked the monks,

pli-tv-kd5:1.14.5.pli: “kassa nvāyaṃ, bhikkhave, caṅkamo lohitena phuṭo, seyyathāpi gavāghātanan”ti?
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.5.eng: “Whose walking path is this? It’s covered in blood, like a slaughterhouse.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.14.6.pli: “Āyasmato, bhante, soṇassa accāraddhavīriyassa caṅkamato pādā bhijjiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.6.eng: They told him what had happened.

pli-tv-kd5:1.14.7.pli: Tassāyaṃ caṅkamo lohitena phuṭo, seyyathāpi gavāghātanan”ti.

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yenāyasmato soṇassa vihāro tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.1.eng: The Buddha then went up to Soṇa’s dwelling and sat down on the prepared seat.

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.2.pli: Āyasmāpi kho soṇo bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ soṇaṃ bhagavā etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.3.eng: and the Buddha said to him,

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.4.pli: “nanu te, soṇa, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.4.eng: “Soṇa, while reflecting in private, didn’t you think,

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.5.pli: ‘ye kho keci bhagavato sāvakā āraddhavīriyā viharanti, ahaṃ tesaṃ aññataro.
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.5.eng: ‘I’m one of the Buddha’s energetic disciples,

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.6.pli: Atha ca pana me nānupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccati.
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.6.eng: yet my mind isn’t freed from the corruptions through letting go.

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.7.pli: Saṃvijjanti kho pana me kule bhogā;

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.8.pli: sakkā bhoge ca bhuñjituṃ, puññāni ca kātuṃ.

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.9.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjeyyaṃ, puññāni ca kareyyan’”ti?
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.9.eng: Why don’t I return to the lower life, enjoy wealth, and make merit’?”

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.11.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa, kusalo tvaṃ pubbe agārikabhūto vīṇāya tantissare”ti?
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.11.eng: “Well, let me ask you, Soṇa: when you were previously a householder, weren’t you a skilled lute player?”

pli-tv-kd5:1.15.13.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa, yadā te vīṇāya tantiyo accāyatā honti, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti, kammaññā vā”ti?
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.13.eng: “When the strings were too tight, was the lute in tune and easy to play?”

pli-tv-kd5:1.16.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa, yadā te vīṇāya tantiyo atisithilā honti, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti, kammaññā vā”ti?
pli-tv-kd5:1.16.1.eng: “When the strings were too loose, was the lute in tune and easy to play?”

pli-tv-kd5:1.16.3.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, soṇa, yadā te vīṇāya tantiyo neva accāyatā honti nātisithilā, same guṇe patiṭṭhitā, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṃ samaye saravatī vā hoti, kammaññā vā”ti?
pli-tv-kd5:1.16.3.eng: “But when the strings were neither too tight nor too loose, but set to a balanced tension, was the lute then in tune and easy to play?”

pli-tv-kd5:1.16.5.pli: “Evameva kho, soṇa, accāraddhavīriyaṃ uddhaccāya saṃvattati, atilīnavīriyaṃ kosajjāya saṃvattati.
pli-tv-kd5:1.16.5.eng: “Just so, Soṇa, too much energy leads to restlessness and too little to laziness.

pli-tv-kd5:1.17.1.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, soṇa, vīriyasamataṃ adhiṭṭhaha, indriyānañca samataṃ paṭivijjha, tattha ca nimittaṃ gaṇhāhī”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.17.1.eng: So apply a balanced energy and bring about an evenness in the spiritual faculties. And that is where you should take up the meditation object.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.17.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā soṇo bhagavato paccassosi.

pli-tv-kd5:1.17.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ soṇaṃ iminā ovādena ovaditvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—sītavane āyasmato soṇassa sammukhe antarahito gijjhakūṭe pabbate pāturahosi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.17.3.eng: Then, as a strong man might bend or stretch his arm, the Buddha disappeared from the presence of Soṇa in Cool Grove and appeared on the Vulture Peak.

pli-tv-kd5:1.18.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā soṇo aparena samayena vīriyasamataṃ adhiṭṭhāsi, indriyānañca samataṃ paṭivijjhi, tattha ca nimittaṃ aggahesi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.1.eng: Soon Soṇa applied a balanced energy and brought about an evenness in his spiritual faculties, which is where he took up his meditation object.

pli-tv-kd5:1.18.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā soṇo, eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto, na cirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.2.eng: He then stayed by himself, secluded, heedful, energetic, and diligent. In no long time in this very life, he realized with his own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life for which gentlemen rightly go forth into homelessness.

pli-tv-kd5:1.18.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abhiññāsi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.3.eng: He understood that birth had come to an end, that the spiritual life had been fulfilled, that the job had been done, that there was no further state of existence.

pli-tv-kd5:1.18.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā soṇo arahataṃ ahosi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.4.eng: And Venerable Soṇa became one of the perfected ones.

pli-tv-kd5:1.19.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato soṇassa arahattappattassa etadahosi—

pli-tv-kd5:1.19.2.eng: “Why don’t I declare perfect insight to the Buddha?”

pli-tv-kd5:1.19.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā soṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd5:1.19.3.eng: He then went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd5:1.19.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā soṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd5:1.20.1.pli: “yo so, bhante, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto, so chaṭṭhānāni adhimutto hoti—
pli-tv-kd5:1.20.1.eng: “Sir, a monk who is a perfected one—who has ended the corruptions, fulfilled the spiritual life, done the job, put down the burden, realized the true goal, cut the bond to existence, gained release by right insight—he is committed to six things:

pli-tv-kd5:1.20.2.pli: nekkhammādhimutto hoti, pavivekādhimutto hoti, abyāpajjādhimutto hoti, upādānakkhayādhimutto hoti, taṇhakkhayādhimutto hoti, asammohādhimutto hoti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.20.2.eng: to renunciation, seclusion, harmlessness, the end of grasping, the end of craving, and non-confusion.

pli-tv-kd5:1.21.1.pli: Siyā kho pana, bhante, idhekaccassa āyasmato evamassa—

pli-tv-kd5:1.21.2.pli: ‘kevalaṃ saddhāmattakaṃ nūna ayamāyasmā nissāya nekkhammādhimutto’ti, na kho panetaṃ, bhante, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.21.2.eng: ‘No doubt this venerable is committed to renunciation simply because of faith.’ But this would be the wrong way to look at it.

pli-tv-kd5:1.21.3.pli: Khīṇāsavo, bhante, bhikkhu, vusitavā, katakaraṇīyo, karaṇīyamattānaṃ asamanupassanto katassa vā paṭicayaṃ khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā nekkhammādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā nekkhammādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā nekkhammādhimutto hoti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.21.3.eng: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has fulfilled the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself, nor anything that needs improving. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.

pli-tv-kd5:1.22.1.pli: Siyā kho pana, bhante, idhekaccassa āyasmato evamassa—

pli-tv-kd5:1.22.2.eng: ‘No doubt this venerable is committed to seclusion because he desires material support, honor, and praise.’

pli-tv-kd5:1.22.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, bhante, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.22.3.eng: But this would be the wrong way to look at it.

pli-tv-kd5:1.22.4.pli: Khīṇāsavo, bhante, bhikkhu, vusitavā, katakaraṇīyo, karaṇīyamattānaṃ asamanupassanto katassa vā paṭicayaṃ, khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā pavivekādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā pavivekādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā pavivekādhimutto hoti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.22.4.eng: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has fulfilled the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself, nor anything that needs improving. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.

pli-tv-kd5:1.23.1.pli: Siyā kho pana, bhante, idhekaccassa āyasmato evamassa—

pli-tv-kd5:1.23.2.eng: ‘No doubt this venerable is committed to non-harming because he falls back on adhering to virtue and vows as the essence.’

pli-tv-kd5:1.23.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, bhante, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.23.3.eng: But this would be the wrong way to look at it.

pli-tv-kd5:1.23.4.pli: Khīṇāsavo, bhante, bhikkhu, vusitavā, katakaraṇīyo, karaṇīyamattānaṃ asamanupassanto katassa vā paṭicayaṃ, khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā abyāpajjādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā abyāpajjādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā abyāpajjādhimutto hoti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.23.4.eng: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has fulfilled the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself, nor anything that needs improving. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.

pli-tv-kd5:1.24.1.pli: Khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā upādānakkhayādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā upādānakkhayādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā upādānakkhayādhimutto hoti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.24.1.eng: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire.

pli-tv-kd5:1.24.2.pli: Khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā taṇhakkhayādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā taṇhakkhayādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā taṇhakkhayādhimutto hoti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.24.2.eng: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will.

pli-tv-kd5:1.24.3.pli: Khayā rāgassa vītarāgattā asammohādhimutto hoti, khayā dosassa vītadosattā asammohādhimutto hoti, khayā mohassa vītamohattā asammohādhimutto hoti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.24.3.eng: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.

pli-tv-kd5:1.25.1.pli: Evaṃ sammā vimuttacittassa, bhante, bhikkhuno bhusā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.1.eng: Sir, for a monk who is fully freed in this way, even if he sees compelling sights, his mind is not overpowered by them.

pli-tv-kd5:1.25.2.pli: Amissīkatamevassa cittaṃ hoti, ṭhitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ, vayañcassānupassati.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.2.eng: It remains unaffected, steady, and unshakeable, and he observes its disappearance.

pli-tv-kd5:1.25.3.eng: Even if he hears compelling sounds,

pli-tv-kd5:1.25.7.pli: manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti;
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.7.eng: or experiences compelling mental phenomena, his mind is not overpowered by them.

pli-tv-kd5:1.25.8.pli: amissīkatamevassa cittaṃ hoti, ṭhitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ, vayañcassānupassati.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.8.eng: It remains unaffected, steady, and unshakeable, and he observes its disappearance.

pli-tv-kd5:1.26.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, selo pabbato acchiddo asusiro ekagghano, puratthimāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi, neva naṃ saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampavedheyya;
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.1.eng: It’s just like a granite mountain, a single, solid mass without cracks. It doesn’t shake or tremble when a powerful rainstorm arrives from any direction.

pli-tv-kd5:1.26.2.pli: pacchimāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi …pe…

pli-tv-kd5:1.26.4.pli: dakkhiṇāya cepi disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi, neva naṃ saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampavedheyya;

pli-tv-kd5:1.26.5.pli: evameva kho, bhante, evaṃ sammā vimuttacittassa bhikkhuno bhusā cepi cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti;
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.5.eng: The mind of the monk who is fully freed in this way is just like that.

pli-tv-kd5:1.26.6.pli: amissīkatamevassa cittaṃ hoti, ṭhitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ, vayañcassānupassati.

pli-tv-kd5:1.26.11.pli: manoviññeyyā dhammā manassa āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, nevassa cittaṃ pariyādiyanti;

pli-tv-kd5:1.26.12.pli: amissīkatamevassa cittaṃ hoti, ṭhitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ, vayañcassānupassatī”ti.

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.2.eng: And to seclusion of the mind,

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.4.eng: And to the end of grasping,

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.5.eng: For one committed to the end of craving

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.7.eng: Having seen the arising of the senses,

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.9.eng: For one who is fully freed,

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.10.eng: The monastic with a peaceful mind,

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.13.eng: Just as a single, solid rock,

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.15.eng: So too, all sights, and sounds,

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.17.eng: And mental objects, good or bad,

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.18.eng: Cannot move that kind of person.

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.19.eng: Their mind is free and steady,

pli-tv-kd5:1.27.20.eng: And they observe it as it disappears.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.28.0.eng: 2. The prohibition against sandals with double-layered soles, etc.

pli-tv-kd5:1.28.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd5:1.28.2.pli: “evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kulaputtā aññaṃ byākaronti, attho ca vutto, attā ca anupanīto.
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.2.eng: “It’s in this way that a gentleman declares perfect insight. The matter is spoken of, but the person isn’t mentioned.

pli-tv-kd5:1.28.3.pli: Atha ca panidhekacce moghapurisā hasamānakaṃ maññe aññaṃ byākaronti, te pacchā vighātaṃ āpajjantī”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.3.eng: Still some foolish men here seem to declare perfect insight just for fun. Soon enough they experience distress.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.29.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ soṇaṃ āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.1.eng: The Buddha then said to Soṇa,

pli-tv-kd5:1.29.2.eng: “Soṇa, you were brought up in great comfort.

pli-tv-kd5:1.29.3.eng: I allow you to use sandals with single-layered soles.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.29.4.pli: “Ahaṃ kho, bhante, asītisakaṭavāhe hiraññaṃ ohāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, sattahatthikañca anīkaṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.4.eng: “When I went forth into homelessness, sir, I left behind eighty cartloads of gold coins and a troop of seven elephants.
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.4.comm: “Gold coins” renders hirañña. See Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd5:1.29.5.pli: Athāhaṃ, bhante, ekapalāsikañce upāhanaṃ pariharissāmi, tassa me bhavissanti vattāro ‘soṇo koḷiviso asītisakaṭavāhe hiraññaṃ ohāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, sattahatthikañca anīkaṃ.
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.5.eng: If I were to walk around in sandals with single-layered soles, some people would say, ‘Soṇa left all this behind when he went forth,

pli-tv-kd5:1.29.6.eng: and now he’s attached to sandals with single-layered soles.’

pli-tv-kd5:1.30.1.pli: Sace bhagavā bhikkhusaṅghassa anujānissati ahampi paribhuñjissāmi;
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.1.eng: If you allow them to the Sangha of monks, I too will use them.

pli-tv-kd5:1.30.2.pli: no ce bhagavā bhikkhusaṅghassa anujānissati, ahampi na paribhuñjissāmī”ti.
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.2.eng: If not, I won’t use them either.”

pli-tv-kd5:1.30.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.3.eng: The Buddha then gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd5:1.30.5.eng: But you shouldn’t wear sandals with double-layered soles,

pli-tv-kd5:1.30.8.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd5:2.1.0.eng: 3. The prohibition against what is entirely blue, etc.

pli-tv-kd5:2.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū sabbanīlikā upāhanāyo dhārenti …pe…
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.1.eng: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six wore entirely blue sandals,

pli-tv-kd5:2.1.9.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd5:2.1.11.eng: “You shouldn’t wear sandals that are entirely blue,

pli-tv-kd5:2.1.12.pli: na sabbapītikā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na sabbalohitikā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na sabbamañjiṭṭhikā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na sabbakaṇhā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na sabbamahāraṅgarattā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na sabbamahānāmarattā upāhanā dhāretabbā.
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.12.eng: entirely yellow, entirely red, entirely magenta, entirely black, entirely orange, or entirely beige.
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.12.comm: According to SED, the mahāraṅga (sv. mahārajana) is the safflower, which is normally deep yellow or orange. Sp 3.246: Mahānāmarattā sambhinnavaṇṇā hoti paṇḍupalāsavaṇṇā, “Mahānāmaratta is a mixed color, the color of withered leaves.”

pli-tv-kd5:2.1.13.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd5:2.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū nīlakavaddhikā upāhanāyo dhārenti …pe…
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals with blue straps,

pli-tv-kd5:2.2.2.pli: pītakavaddhikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, lohitakavaddhikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, mañjiṭṭhikavaddhikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, kaṇhavaddhikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, mahāraṅgarattavaddhikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, mahānāmarattavaddhikā upāhanāyo dhārenti.
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.2.eng: yellow straps, red straps, magenta straps, black straps, orange straps, and beige straps.

pli-tv-kd5:2.2.4.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd5:2.2.6.pli: “Na, bhikkhave, nīlakavaddhikā upāhanā dhāretabbā …pe… na pītakavaddhikā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na lohitakavaddhikā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na mañjiṭṭhikavaddhikā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na kaṇhavaddhikā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na mahāraṅgarattavaddhikā upāhanā dhāretabbā, na mahānāmarattavaddhikā upāhanā dhāretabbā.
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.6.eng: “You shouldn’t wear sandals with blue straps, yellow straps, red straps, magenta straps, black straps, orange straps, or beige straps.

pli-tv-kd5:2.2.7.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd5:2.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū khallakabaddhā upāhanāyo dhārenti …pe… puṭabaddhā upāhanāyo dhārenti, pāliguṇṭhimā upāhanāyo dhārenti, tūlapuṇṇikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, tittirapattikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, meṇḍavisāṇavaddhikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, ajavisāṇavaddhikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, vicchikāḷikā upāhanāyo dhārenti, morapiñchaparisibbitā upāhanāyo dhārenti, citrā upāhanāyo dhārenti.
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals containing leather, enclosing the shin and the foot, covering the foot, stuffed with cotton, looking like partridge feathers, having straps like ram horns, having straps like goat horns, having straps like scorpion claws, decorated with a peacock’s tail feather, and decorated in various ways.

pli-tv-kd5:2.3.3.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd5:2.3.5.comm: Sp 3.246: Khallakabaddhāti paṇhipidhānatthaṁ tale khallakaṁ bandhitvā katā, “Khallakabaddha: they are made by fastening leather at the sole for the purpose of covering the heel.” Vmv 3.246 adds: Khallakanti sabbapaṇhipidhānacammaṁ, “Khallaka: a skin to cover the entire heel.”

Sp 3.246: Puṭabaddhāti yonakaupāhanā vuccati, yā yāvajaṅghato sabbapādaṁ paṭicchādeti, “Greek sandals are called puṭabaddha: whatever covers the entire foot as far as the shin.” Sp 3.246: Pāliguṇṭhimāti paliguṇṭhitvā katā; yā upari pādamattameva paṭicchādeti, na jaṅghaṁ, “Pāliguṇṭhima: they are made by covering: whatever covers merely the top of the foot, but not the shin.” Sp 3.246: Tūlapuṇṇikāti tūlapicunā pūretvā katā, “Tūlapuṇṇika: they are made by filling with cotton down.” Sp 3.246: Tittirapattikāti tittirapattasadisā vicittabaddhā, “Tittirapattika: they are colored, like the feathers of a partridge.” Sp 3.246: Meṇḍavisāṇavaddhikāti kaṇṇikaṭṭhāne meṇḍakasiṅgasaṇṭhāne vaddhe yojetvā katā, “Meṇḍavisāṇavaddhika: they are made by connecting a strap with the appearance of a ram horn at one corner.” Sp 3.246: Vicchikāḷikāpi tattheva vicchikanaṅguṭṭhasaṇṭhāne vaddhe yojetvā katā, “Vicchikāḷika: they are made by connecting a strap with the appearance of scorpion claw.” Sp 3.246: Morapiñchaparisibbitāti talesu vā vaddhesu vā morapiñchehi suttakasadisehi parisibbitā, “Morapiñchaparisibbita: the tail feather of a peacock is sewn on the sole or on the strap, like a string of beads.”

pli-tv-kd5:2.3.7.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd5:2.4.5.eng: “You shouldn’t wear sandals decorated with lionskin,

pli-tv-kd5:3.1.0.eng: 4. The allowance for second-hand sandals with multi-layered soles

pli-tv-kd5:3.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi, aññatarena bhikkhunā pacchāsamaṇena.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.1.eng: One morning the Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Rājagaha for almsfood together with an attendant monk.

pli-tv-kd5:3.1.2.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu khañjamāno bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.2.eng: As the attendant followed behind the Buddha, he was limping.

pli-tv-kd5:3.1.3.pli: Addasā kho aññataro upāsako guṇaṅguṇūpāhanā ārohitvā bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ;
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.3.eng: A certain lay follower wearing sandals with multi-layered soles saw the Buddha coming.

pli-tv-kd5:3.1.4.pli: disvā upāhanā ārohitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami;

pli-tv-kd5:3.1.4.comm: I read orohitvā with the PTS version, against ārohitvā in MS. The MS text is saying that he is already wearing sandals, but then puts them on before going to meet the Buddha, which does not make good sense.

pli-tv-kd5:3.1.5.eng: He then bowed to the attendant monk and asked him,

pli-tv-kd5:3.2.5.eng: But the Buddha said, “Please take the sandals.”

pli-tv-kd5:6.4.11.eng: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd5:6.4.12.comm: The shoe, pādukā, is introduced in this section, as distinct from the upāhanā, “sandal”, of the previous sections. They are both footwear and the distinction between them is not obvious. The best indication as to the difference is found at Sp-yoj 2.638: Pādukanti upāhanaviseso. So hi pajjate imāyāti pādukāti vuccati, sā bahupaṭalā cammamayā vā hoti kaṭṭhamayā vā, “A pāduka: it is distinct from an upāhana. It is called a pāduka, because one should walk with it. It has much covering made of skin or wood.” Here the distinction between the two appears to hinge on the amount of covering, and thus translating the two terms as “shoe” and “sandal” seems justified. Moreover, the distinction made in Bhikkhu Ṭhānissaro’s “The Buddhist Monastic Code I”, p. 444, and “The Buddhist Monastic Code II”, chapter III, that upāhāna refers to leather footwear whereas pāduka refers to non-leather footwear is here contradicted: it is specifically stated that a pāduka can be made of leather.
